author: {'steamid': '76561198081717760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1707856494}
review:
THIS! This is how you play the OG Serious Sam Games on a modern system! Alligator Pit has crafted the perfect Serious Sam single player and multiplayer experience into a cohesive, explosive package, and implemented every tweak imaginable to make the gameplay as accommodating and seamless to modern Windows 10 and 11 PC's as you can imagine. The best is that they did so while perfectly preserving the original games... YOU EVEN GET AN EAX SOUND OPTION (which I activated using Alchemy)! They also added some new stuff which I will try as soon as I finish the OG games.

If you are a Serious Sam fan and you don't own this already... what the hell is wrong with you!? Perhaps you should go consider another hobby like collecting tyres or starting a your own Wiki page on the types of dust mites most commonly found in movie theatres.

If you are a Serious Sam fan expecting a baby soon DO NOT PLAY THIS. You might name your child after the developers. Trust me, this is a bad idea. Just think of how they would be mocked at school! Then their self esteem would be so low they wouldn't have the backbone to try Serious Sam Classics: Revolution for themselves. That would be a REAL tradgedy (even bigger than taking up their daddy's tyre collection hobby).

author: {'steamid': '76561198448401760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6448, 'last_played': 1705155244}
review:
Si buscas jugar Serious Sam, compra el pack HD Gold Edition, junto al 3 Gold Edition, as√≠ tienes todo el contenido disponible en Serious Sam Fusion que es la manera definitiva de probar la franquicia (El Pack HD incluye este juego, que no recomendar√≠a jugar)

Serious Sam Classics Revolution es una idea que en principio suena fenomenal, remasterizar las entregas m√°s viejas usando el mismo motor y trayendo nuevos agregados como una nueva dificultad (Extremadamente dif√≠cil), una nueva campa√±a (Bastante disfrutable) y un apartado de mods para enchular nuestro juego a gusto (Bastante mejorable)

El problema viene cuando vemos que el online de esta cosa es disfuncional, hay veces que en el modo cooperativo las partidas no sincronizan, y es molesto y absurdo que un juego de nuestra √©poca tenga un Deathmatch sin cambio autom√°tico de mapa; Esto quiere decir, que cuando acabes de jugar, el juego se congelar√° hasta que decidas quitarlo y abrir una nueva partida, absurdo, considerando que los Serious Sam viejos ten√≠an servidores muy buenos cuando exist√≠a GameSpy.

Otro problema son la selecci√≥n de mods, a diferencia de Serious Sam Fusion que tiene 2 versiones (Una normal y otra modeable), este juego carece de una opci√≥n as√≠, y como tampoco tiene un apartado para activar y desactivar mods, en ocasiones habr√°n combinaciones de armas que tu no deseaste. 

Pese a ser mi primer Serious Sam, aprecio que me haya introducido a la franquicia, pero luego de jugar Fusion por muchas horas, no puedo ver este recopilatorio de la misma manera.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116951645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3120, 'last_played': 1702699758}
review:
NOTE: Review based on Serious difficulty mode.

Serious Sam Classics: Revolution is a mod for Serious Sam 1 (The First and The Second Encounters) developed by fan group Alligator Pit. It has some bug fixes and some extras, notably the Bright Island campaign, 6 (+2 secret) new levels.

Not much new to say about Serious Sam 1, it's old school FPS goodness at its finest. Each map has thousands of enemies (depending on difficulty), and the game doesn't hesitate to throw a couple hundred at a time at you. Adapt or die. Croteam also knows when to relax the mayhem a bit, so the pacing is enjoyable. The maps have a ton of secrets to discover and there is a nice variety to them, so if you like to uncover everything there is quite a bit of replayability value in there. In this version you can play both Encounters back to back for convenience, as well.

Sadly the Bright Island maps (developed by Alligator Pit) are a step down from Croteam's games, due to in my opinion a misunderstanding of what makes Serious Sam fun. The Encounters are tough, yes, but fair. Apart from a couple annoying gimmick rooms there is always ample space to maneuver and the enemy combinations are never terrible. This is not the case on Bright Island. Small, cramped space (sometimes with bottomless pits surrounding them), terrible enemy combinations in excessive numbers, platforming sections... Honestly, the maps feel designed to piss you off rather than to offer a challenge. And that's exactly it, Serious Sam 1 is challenging, Bright Island is frustrating. They are not terrible maps and if you are a masochist or just really want more SS they are ok, but don't expect the same level of quality Croteam provides in regards to the design.

Apart from the campaign levels you also have trial runs which might be fun for a challenge or multiplayer deathmatch, but I can't speak in regards to this last one.

In conclusion, even if the new content is not stellar, at its heart it's still Serious Sam 1 goodness. What's not to love?

author: {'steamid': '76561198067706801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 12469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12437, 'last_played': 1708291563}
review:
Ahh where to start... How to completely RUIN a masterpiece like Serious Sam Classic.

Worst. most bugged release in the whole series... I'd go as far and say it's the buggiest game I ever played.
As a life long Serious Sam fan, and spent countless hours in each game of the series (especially the first two)

Revolution is a prime example of "don't try to fix what ain't broken". This game is impossible to play with others, aka multiplayer doesn't work, I even tried it with a friend in the same room, and the latency was insane.
Completely unplayable. 

The achievements don't want to register, or work. I completed some of the "challenges" (which are a complete joke btw)
The foliage is broken, aka the draw distance sucks and can't be improved via menu, things like chimneys, decorations and trees disappear from your sight after like 1-2 meters.

the "Bright Island" campaign, is just a bunch of fan made levels and reused design from alpha maps (the 2 secret levels), and they even managed to screw that up. You can sense the amateurism in the enemy spawn count and their spread. There is a way Croteam balances enemies, in the way, number and place they spawn. Bright Island completely missed all that. 
It's a broken, laggy experience, the maps hardly even work, and they don't even look that good for the engine to struggle that much. There are maps and mods that look more like a UE2/Source game and play flawlessly.

The Ghostbuster Beam Gun has been completely broken! It can't destroy objects like statues, or trees for that matter, the beam has a way too short range, the firing rate is too high for such little damage. The beam sometimes doesn't even hurt enemies, like the hits don't register and it goes through them. They managed to completely throw that weapon to waste.
Worst fact is, the code from Croteams official SDK released 20+ years ago works completely fine and doesn't have any of these issues... Hell, even the first early access beta of SSR doesn't have these issues! I won't even mention the other 2 weapons from Seriously Warped Deathmatch (Plasma Thrower and Mine Layer)... They literally looked and worked just fine
the changes made, and position on screen just looks awful.

Fan made patches for TFE and TSE work better, have much more options, can run SSR custom content and maps, are server compatible, are optimized for modern monitors and the HUD doesn't require a microscope to read the text.
Hence, there are absolutely NO excuses for an official release, on Steam, to be this broken.

Some smaller, but annoying bugs include: Broken mechanic for exiting the water, no damage registered upon shooting foes, mouse latency, wrong rendering of Flamethrowers canister, wrong rendering of the position of the flame that comes out of it in 21:9 monitors, same applies for the Ghostbuster, random crashes in the Bright Island campaign....

Again, don't fix what ain't broken. The concept is good, but the execution is sucks!
Croteam, stop being lazy, and fix the issues present in classic properly, add constructive and important new features,
and don't break what's working for god's sake!


I completely recommend both Serious Sam Classic games, but absolutely don't recommend SS Revolution!

review: Serious Sam is a series of a games that were developed by Croteam and is a old-school no-nonsense FPS. Just kidding about old-school, it's more of a arcade-ish horde fighting game, more focused on shooting down tons of enemies rather than exploring mazes, all while Quake 1 was struggling to have more than few enemies on a screen. But hey, when there was so many military shooters, you couldn't be picky.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021400166', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1637, 'last_played': 1703543988}
review:
Everything what's best from 1st and 2nd Encounter plus some nonsense achievements and random game crashes. Controls are messed up, if you play it make sure to check and rebind what was changed.

This compilation offers nothing more but what original have plus an extra map to play, however originals are more stable and you don't have run the game five times counting for this next to open properly.

Pros:
+ free
+ extra map to play
+ new secrets and weapons

Cones:
- lots of issues upon starting the game (program not responding)
- nonsense multiplayer achievements for the game that is dead in this mode
- nonsense single player achievements forcing you to save/load to grind the time
- controls messed up by default

author: {'steamid': '76561197996540994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1695160167}
review:
Still need HELP!

OK I found out how to read the messages.(Mouse button 3).  Not at all the same as previous games. But USE button is still a mystery as is the sniper zoom button. I cant look through the scope.
Also don't seem to be able to find a way to the other lvls. Is the Island complete or is it a demo?

__________________________________
Most definitely a bug in this game.  I tried loading The First Encounter through it and the "Use" button worked until a "Press the Use Button" message popped up.  Then it would not work at all. 
I have the stand alone version of First Encounter and Second Encounter and double clicking the right mouse button works for "Use" in those.  But when I reassign to right mouse button in Revolution it doesn't work and I can't find an option to allow double click and the"E" button doesn't work.
The Island stuff (3rd game option) the "Use" button (E) hasn't worked at all.  I haven't tried loading The Second Encounter through it.
Anyway I can't read the messages that pop up through in the message box when I kill a new monster or pick up a new weapon without a way to open the messages window
What little bit I played looks interesting but sorry, I can't recommend a game that is not fully functional.
I also noticed that when I first open steam and click play. during the load screens there are a bunch of red "failed to load" messages at the top of the page.  They cycle off too fast for me to read the full messages. But if I reload the game without logging off steam, they do not repeat.
Yes my windows 10 is up to date.
If anyone knows a fix I would appreciate if you could post it.  I would be glad to change to thumbs up if I can get the game to work correctly.

They gave a lot of not very necessary settings, but I still didn‚Äôt understand where to change the graphic api from opengl to direct3d.

A dubious revolution, albeit for free..

‚öñÔ∏è iMeter {A} Worth a play, if you enjoy nostalgia casual coop gunplay. However, if you're looking for HD graphic with 120++ fps, don't play it

[h1] ‚≠êÔ∏è         COMPARE TO FIRST ENCOUNTER:[/h1]
* Added Chainsaw, Sniper weapon, Flamer
* Added new enemies
* Added power-ups (double damage / running boost)
* Added bouncer platform
* Added serious bomb
* Added harmful encounters
* Added mixture of enemies to increase frustration
* Added repeat combat in a same area

[h1] üíé         COMPARE TO OTHERS SAME GENRE:[/h1]
* Very easy at beginning, very hard at the end
* Many secret area to be discover
* Capable to coop up to 16 players 
* Optional Survival mode with diverse maps
* Steam workshop support

[h1]  üîä         TESTER MUST KNOW:[/h1]
* Well optimized for modern PC (decent wide screen)
* Game world timeline: Travel back to B.C. 1378, Egypt 
* Sirius = Aliens from a real planet
* Steam screenshot must set to F11
* This version contain: First Encounter + Second Encounter + Bright Island
* Bright Island = Extra campaign
* First Encounter is made for solo fun, playing coop will too easy
* Second Encounter is made for coop teamwork, playing solo will be tiring easily
* Serious bomb = instant death with a smile, affect 700ft in range
* Added Plasma-thrower into Citadel, from Warped Deathmatch
* Using console cheats disable Steam Achievement

[h1]  ‚ö†Ô∏è        RUMOR CHECKING:[/h1]
* Worth buying at full price ‚ûú Worth it, because great amount of contents
* Early Access for 5+ years and being abandon ‚ûú Doesn't means it is a bad package
* Multiplayer is Dead ‚ûú Doesn't means it is a bad game
* Wasted Potential ‚ûú Disagree

author: {'steamid': '76561199084679099', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2171, 'last_played': 1686389048}
review: I really like on how this game is just the original Serious Sam but with achievements, and extra stuff included within it. You can change the HUD to your liking, you can use workshop items made by amazing people in this game, and you can play SPLITSCREEN on ONE SINGLE SETUP (1 keyboard and 1 mouse). Makes the game even more good because fans actually work on this. Super enjoyable. A few problems would be Sam I Am, where you legit spend 14 hours or some sort just grinding kills, and the game basically being dead. Otherwise, a good game to get when you get the Serious Sam bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561199152900910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 8, 'playtime_at_review': 3888, 'last_played': 1710144178}
review:
I am Sam. I am Sam. Sam-I-Am..

That Sam-I-Am! That Sam-I-Am! I do not like that Sam-I-Am!

Do you like green eggs and ham?

I do not like them, Sam-I-Am.
I do not like green eggs and ham.

Would you like them here or there?

I would not like them here or there.
I would not like them anywhere.
I do not like green eggs and ham.
I do not like them, Sam-I-Am.

Would you like them in a house?
Would you like them with a mouse?

I do not like them in a house.
I do not like them with a mouse.
I do not like them here or there.
I do not like them anywhere.
I do not like green eggs and ham.
I do not like them, Sam-I-Am.

Would you eat them in a box?
Would you eat them with a fox?

Not in a box. Not with a fox.
Not in a house. Not with a mouse.
I would not eat them here or there.
I would not eat them anywhere.
I would not eat green eggs and ham.
I do not like them, Sam-I-Am.

Would you? Could you? In a car?
Eat them! Eat them! Here they are.

I would not, could not, in a car.

You may like them. You will see.
You may like them in a tree!

I would not, could not in a tree.
Not in a car! You let me be.

Could you, would you, with a goat?

I would not, could not with a goat!

Would you, could you, on a boat?

I could not, would not, on a boat.
I will not, will not, with a goat.
I will not eat them in the rain.
Not in the dark! Not in a tree!
Not in a car! You let me be!
I do not like them in a box.
I do not like them with a fox.
I will not eat them in a house.
I do not like them with a mouse.
I do not like them here or there.
I do not like them anywhere!
I do not like green eggs and ham!
I do not like them, Sam-I-Am.

You do not like them. So you say.
Try them! Try them! And you may.
Try them and you may, I say.

Sam! If you let me be,
I will try them. You will see.

Say! I like green eggs and ham!
I do! I like them, Sam-I-Am!
And I would eat them in a boat.
And I would eat them with a goat...
And I will eat them, in the rain.
And in the dark. And on a train.
And in a car. And in a tree.
They are so good, so good, you see!
So I will eat them in a box.
And I will eat them with a fox.
And I will eat them in a house.
And I will eat them with a mouse.
And I will eat them here and there.
Say! I will eat them anywhere!
I do so like green eggs and ham!
Thank you! Thank you, Sam-I-Am.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028199661', 'num_games_owned': 2504, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 13143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10772, 'last_played': 1684404100}
review:
To Be Honest I really do not know how to review this package. I was very tempted to negative review a Serious Sam game for the first time in my life that too classics I love! I loved the original classic games a lot played dozens of times of CD packs. Even bought Gold pack which let me down seeing only bonus it had was an amateurish incomplete fan made 3 map buggy Dark Island mission. When Revolutions was announced I was skeptical. I was not wrong it took many years to make this workable. Fans turned Devs were in charge. The present version is the best working one. So let me list what I do not like about it at present:

The grind of achievements. Having played classics, BFE, HD versions, Fusion all having own set of grinds this one is nerve wrecking most. Some achievements need you to play same TSE Seirra De Chaipas half a dozen times to beat map without taking damage, replay ending exit twice using only knife no weapon else, to not kill more than 7 enemies [the first room of building is crucial where Pumpkin breaks out of wall], on normal modes. Game does not work as well as standalone classic version because they have made it a grind so some things have deliberately been messed like rocket jumping. They have added achievement for Ugh Zhan Mode that is really beating enemies 400x without modification of unlimited ammo in either TFE or TSE final boss maps. The Devs insist you face every enemy and kill it not jump out of arena to hide on a wall or roof. And hence messed rocket jumping up for that reason alone seems, in full game. They added 3 new guns that seem forced and have achievements to find those and use those. It has one compulsary survival mission to play Christmas map that is forced. Allow a gold in any map if needed do not force it on a particular one. I JUST BEAT IT TODAY AFTER LONG ON WRITING THIS REVIEW LOL! Actually I hated it till it was a mess to get on getting it its satisfactory BUT it should not be forced.

[b]TIP[/b]: Do save game lots. Lots of frequent game crashes.

The good parts is its still playable. If you really are a fan of classics if you fancy grinding out the achievements jump in else play solo classics. Thankfully co-op achievements can be unlocked playing just the last boss maps and some vs achievements in split screen mode. A few new secrets got added [Alligator pit in Hatshepsut and finding 3 new weapons in maps later]. The only reason I upvote it is because of love of the game and because you might enjoy some of the survival maps and the Bright island added 8 map campaign. Unlike the Gold CD Dark Island crap, this at least seems fun in many places. It can suffer lags when big fights starts as the maps are big and you may face loading optimization issues with lower GPUs or older machines. If you are an achievement hunter be ready for some frustration. Play it only if achievements don't bother you or challenge. It bothered me truckloads. Most campaign achievements can be obtained on tourist mode thankfully! Achievements grind is a problem I have against Fusion as well. You decide.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026705369', 'num_games_owned': 592, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 3143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3143, 'last_played': 1680324441}
review:
[h1]The First Two Serious Sam Games are some of the best Old School FPS Games you can play and the classic versions of these games are still enjoyable to this day.[/h1]

If you look in my Steam Library, you'll know I've spent hundreds upon hundreds of hours on the Serious Sam series. And there's a good reason why. From it's witty, dad joke, one line spouting lovable main hero, to it's horde based shooter gameplay, to it's colorful personality and excellent music, Croteam's Sam games are seriously (pun intended) timeless and I've pretty much have enjoyed every entry into the series. But I wanted to specifically talk about what makes the first two games in the series so good and what better way to do so than to review this Bundle, which includes modding support and a new fan made expansion called Bright Island.

I'll be talking both about Serious Sam: The First Encounter and The Second Encounter at the same time, so please bare with me. First off, if we're just talking about The First Encounter, it's a strong debut game and quickly was developing many of the series traits and lore. This includes introducing Sam Stone, The Timelock, the villain Mental, it's many iconic enemies and musical themes that would be a mainstay in the series going forward. Serious Sam is Old School Shooter gaming at it's finest and The First Encounter does a great job at showing why. First, the game has good entry points for any person of any experience level. I usually like to play on Tourist just for the Power Fantasy of it all but you can play on harder difficulties if needed. The gameplay of these games are great, throwing hundreds of enemies at you in every level resulting in lightning fast pacing and constant carnage. 

It helps that all the guns are fun to use and are iconic in their own way. Even the Colt Magnums are memorable on their own! They all feel right to use and never are puny when fighting giant enemies, even when taking some of the bigger ones like the Reptiloids or Werebulls down. Some of the guns are so powerful that they can explode enemies into gory chunks, even the double barrel shotgun can decimate a Gnaar quickly up close. A great selection of weapons, but what makes it better is the weapon management. This is one of the best games to handle Weapon Management as every situation is so chaotic that trying to figure out what weapons to use needs quick thinking or preparation before going into another area. This even involves switching weapons on the spot during heavy battles where a variety of enemies can spawn. Even facing spawns of the same enemy can result in changing from something like a Tommy Gun to a Rocket Launcher.

The First Encounter is definitely great, but the game isn't perfect. It's Egypt setting can get stale halfway through as it's mostly the same color scheme throughout and Sam's one liners have not been perfected yet, despite some iconic ones "Here Comes Trouble!" "It ain't the size that matters, it's how you use it!" "AAAAAAAA Yourself!" being the few standouts. But when you get to The Second Encounter, you're pretty much getting what is objectively considered by fans to be the best game in the series. And despite better gameplay, gore, humor, music and graphics in later entries, I could definitely agree on that! Because The Second Encounter introduces more variety in it's levels, a couple new weapons, better jokes, better music and much more graphically pleasing environments. And the game ends with one of the most epic battles in the history of FPS Games that would not be toppled until Serious Sam 4 in my eyes. 

The Second Encounter just improves upon everything The First Encounter did and I still regard it as a major high point of the entire series. There are problems however with each game. For one, the controls have not aged well. They are rather clunky and frustrating especially in parts of The Second Encounter. The Second Encounter also features more "Gimmick Rooms" which are very annoying and I always dread going into one of these rooms as they slow down the pacing to a grinding halt due to their annoying gimmicks. I also have to complain that we do not technically have a canon sequel to this franchise, but considering the revelation that [spoiler]multiverses exist in the Serious Sam series thanks to Serious Sam 4 and Siberian Mayhem[/spoiler] I'm very much interested in where the series can go from here if a proper canon sequel is introduced.

Overall, each game is great, but The Second Encounter is by far the high point of the entire series. It had the perfect blend of one liners, level variety and carnage whilst setting the foundations of the entire Serious Sam series going forward, such as it's huge horde based shooter gameplay, musical themes, interesting lore, iconic enemies and weapons, you name it, these games set the foundations of this EPIC, amazing series.

On another note, there is lots of custom campaigns thanks to modding support for the entire series. Croteam has always been great with lending people modding tools and many have created interesting and cool custom campaigns and levels to try out. The fan made expansion, Bright Island, made by developers Alligator Pit, is not worth playing however. Even though this game runs on a very ancient engine somehow Bright Island manages to drop down in the 30 FPS Range at some points from over 200 FPS at points which is ridiculous. The pacing is also really bad and despite the fact that Serious Sam voice actor John J. D!ck (I have to spell it like that or else it'll be censored) does provide some new lines, nothing stands out. Not worth playing even with the addition of new weapons and enemies.

Still, if you love Old School FPS Games and have heard of this series before but haven't played it yet, these are worth playing. I still recommend the HD Versions with the Fusion 2017 Launcher over the the classics due to better and more smoother feeling controls, but the classics can still be enjoyed due to idiosyncratic things in the engine that aren't possible with newer Serious Sam games on Serious Engines 3 and up. This is probably my favorite series of games despite them not all being perfect mainly due to the modding support, charismatic and hilarious main character, excellent music and brutal horde based carnage. A must have for any FPS Fan!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011296827', 'num_games_owned': 1532, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 2608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1093, 'last_played': 1680853433}
review:
Anyone who says Serious Sam is "mindless" has either never played the game or is bad at it.

When you have 100+ enemies charging and shooting at you, you need to prioritize targets, choose the right weapon for the right enemy and distance, and have excellent spatial awareness and movement to stay alive. Holding the "S" key and shooting will not save you unless you're playing on the easier difficulties.

The colorful and sunny environments with the silly story are a respite from the serious hellish, lovecraftian, and sci-fi settings of more popular FPS.

This series is an underrated gem and if you like retro fps then I recommend giving Serious Sam a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097302596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1679221541}
review:
Serious Sam deserves a special place in gaming history, particularly that of the first-person shooter, as a game that continued to evolve along the lines of the 90's originators of the genre when the rest of the crowd was heading into more-tactical territory that slowed down gameplay in favor of grit or immersion. Instead of doing that, Serious Sam made a clear tongue-in-cheek play at the increasingly "serious" nature of the genre by being anything but actually serious. Decades later, and people who just discover its sequels look at it as a relic of a time it was actually not a part of, because it blends so perfectly into the conventions of that time.

Perhaps a bit too early to call itself "retro" when it wasn't even a decade removed from Wolfenstein 3D or Doom, Serious Sam instead can be seen a bit of a send-up on what were then conventions in the genre: massive waves of enemies with mindlessly-aggressive AI that you mow down with a near-endless supply of bullets spewing from guns that never need reloading. What it does differently from the Dooms, Dukes, and Quakes it parodies is dispense with any notions that it is anything more than mind-numbing fun. No pretentious storylines (although there is a story so to speak), and minimal exploration elements to disrupt from the blasting.

What this means for a modern gamer looking into Serious Sam is you won't have endless backtracking for key cards or sometimes poorly-hidden secrets to dig up, just vast oceans of real estate that make up the games levels set in very colorful environments chock full of fun easter eggs you only have to find if you want a laugh (or some guns a bit early). The Serious Sam Classics Revolution is really just a modernized launcher for the original game that was split into two episodes when first released, supporting modern xinput controls and having more-robust graphical options in-game you'd normally need config file edits or mods to change in the original vanilla game.

I personally toss on the The Xbox mod available in the Workshop for this game, to make guns, character models, and HUD elements resemble the toony forms of the original Xbox port, which was a better look for an already-silly game than the attempts at realism found in the OG PC release. Enemies and environments are completely unchanged besides shaving down the levels to fit on the Xbox, and you don't get the power-ups or combo-scoring found in the Xbox port even with the mod pack on, but the overall feel is the same as the Xbox port, which I think is the superior way to play the first chapter in this series. Any way you take your Sam, it's sure to be serious!

review:
Serious Sam Classics: Revolution zawiera w sobie na dobrƒÖ sprawƒô dwie gry - Serious Sam The Frist Encounter jak i The Second Encounter. W odniesieniu do tego co pamiƒôtam z oryginalnych gier - wprowadzone jest kilka usprawnie≈Ñ i udogodnie≈Ñ. Mo≈ºemy ustawiƒá sobie UI zgodne z naszymi preferencjami, mamy kilka dodatkowych smaczk√≥w (chocia≈ºby plasma gun) oraz Classics: Revolution poprawia z tego co widzƒô generalnƒÖ kompatybilno≈õƒá z nowymi systemami czy z wiƒôkszymi rozdzia≈Çkami. 

Natomiast jak sam gameplay?
Sam gameplay mimo tego, ≈ºe oryginalne gry sƒÖ do≈õƒá wiekowe, zaskakujƒÖco jest r√≥wnie przyjemny i satysfakcjonujƒÖcy co wiele lat wstecz. Jedyne co na pierwszy rzut oka mo≈ºe zniechƒôciƒá, to grafika - kt√≥ra  nie ma co ukrywaƒá, postarza≈Ça siƒô. Jednak je≈õli prze≈Çkniemy to pierwsze wra≈ºenie i rzucimy siƒô w wir walki z przeciwnikami, to po chwili w zasadzie grafika nie bƒôdzie stanowiƒá ≈ºadnego problemu - a przynajmniej tak by≈Ço w moim wypadku. A sama rozgrywka - co tu du≈ºo m√≥wiƒá, tradycyjne naparzanie do kosmit√≥w. Przechodzimy przez wiele poziom√≥w, gdzie za pomocƒÖ dostƒôpnego arsena≈Çu eliminujemy hordy wrog√≥w. 

Z arsena≈Çu mamy dostƒôpnych wiele r√≥≈ºnorodnych broni - od strzelb, po wyrzutnie rakiet, karabiny, miniguny, granatniki, laserowe dzia≈Çko, czy nawet potƒô≈ºnƒÖ armatƒô. W drugiej ods≈Çonie dochodzi snajperka, miotacz ognia. RotujƒÖc tym arsena≈Çem w satysfakcjonujƒÖcy spos√≥b mo≈ºemy pozbywaƒá siƒô fal wrog√≥w. Arsena≈Ç ten jest do≈õƒá satysfakcjonujƒÖcy, pozwala na fajnƒÖ rotacjƒô i dobrƒÖ zabawƒô.

Samo strzelanie - proste i fajne. W przypadku zwyk≈Çych rewolwer√≥w czy karabin√≥w - sprawa jest prosta. Natomiast r√≥≈ºne bronie r√≥≈ºniƒá siƒô bƒôdƒÖ nieco u≈ºyciem. Tak jak w przypadku granatnika trzeba braƒá pewne poprawki, w przypadku armaty mo≈ºemy wystrzeliƒá kulƒô z r√≥≈ºnƒÖ si≈ÇƒÖ, w przypadku rakietnicy nale≈ºy uwa≈ºaƒá na to by siebie nie uszkodziƒá, dzia≈Çko laserowe nieco inaczej r√≥wnie≈º siƒô zachowuje, przez co trzeba braƒá pewne poprawki strzelajƒÖc do ruchomych cel√≥w. Ale o to w tym chodzi. Mimo r√≥≈ºnic w u≈ºyciu (a dobrze, ≈ºe takie sƒÖ) wszystkie bronie sƒÖ u≈ºyteczne i przyjemnie siƒô z nich pruje.

 "Naparzanie do kosmit√≥w" opiera siƒô czƒôsto na dobrym ruchu, odpowiedniej rotacji broniƒÖ, czasami odrobinie taktyki (szybkie zdjƒôcie "zielonych ludk√≥w" rzucajƒÖcych w nas kulkami z auto-aimem, czy wykorzystanie faktu, ≈ºe "kamikaze" biegnƒÖ przy grupie innych wrog√≥w i wysadzenie ich w≈Ça≈õnie wtedy). Do tego wykorzystywanie tego, co daje nam mapa, bonus√≥w (w drugim starciu) czy innych dobrodziejstw. Samej walce i strzelaniu towarzyszy dobre flow. Przeciwnik√≥w jest du≈ºo i sƒÖ zr√≥≈ºnicowani, ale ka≈ºdego szybko siƒô nauczymy - tego jak siƒô zachowuje, jak unikaƒá jego cios√≥w/strza≈Ç√≥w czy jak go najszybciej zniszczyƒá. Mimo "mas√≥wki" i tego, ≈ºe wrog√≥w zw≈Çaszcza p√≥≈∫niej sƒÖ hordy, wszystko jest do≈õƒá przejrzyste. Jest to "czucie" tej akcji. Tu szar≈ºuje na Ciebie horda kleer√≥w (szkielety-koz≈Çy), z oddali prujƒÖ do nas robociki z rakietami... Od drugiej jeszcze kilka byk√≥w. I pomiƒôdzy my, lawirujƒÖcy miƒôdzy hordƒÖ, przeskakujƒÖcy p≈Çynnie od rozwalenia jednej grupki do rozwalenia jeszcze innego przeciwnika. Co≈õ piƒôknego.

Co do przeciwnik√≥w w≈Ça≈õnie - wszyscy sƒÖ zaprojektowani z g≈ÇowƒÖ i jest wystarczajƒÖca ich r√≥≈ºnorodno≈õƒá. Wielu posiada bardzo charakterystyczny wyglƒÖd, co sprawia ≈ºe mimo wiekowej grafiki, prezentujƒÖ siƒô naprawdƒô fajnie. I po ka≈ºdym wiemy czego siƒô spodziewaƒá.

S≈Çowo jeszcze wzglƒôdem designu poziom√≥w i soundtracku. Zw≈Çaszcza w drugim starciu jest on po prostu znakomity. Poziomy zawierajƒÖ masƒô sekret√≥w, kt√≥re mo≈ºemy odkryƒá wa≈ÇƒôsajƒÖc siƒô i zaglƒÖdajƒÖc w r√≥≈ºne miejsca. Do tego miejsca starƒá sƒÖ dobrze zaprojektowane, czasami mamy co≈õ na kszta≈Çt pospolitych aren, czasami korytarze, czasami jeszcze inne warianty. Okazyjnie napotkamy na drodze drobne zagadki czy cele do wykonania - znalezienie kluczy, masek by odblokowaƒá przej≈õcie dalej. Czasami p≈Çywanie i szukanie pod wodƒÖ w labiryncie korytarzy przej≈õcia, czasami odnalezienie d≈∫wigni. To przyjemne przerywniki - podczas kt√≥rych ≈Çatwo te≈º natknƒÖƒá siƒô na wspomniane sekrety. Niekt√≥re przestrzenie na poziomach sƒÖ BARDZO rozleg≈Çe i pozwalajƒÖ nam naprawdƒô na wiele ≈Ça≈ºenia. Jednocze≈õnie nie czuƒá jakiego≈õ poczucia pustki, a jedynie dodajƒÖ rozleg≈Çe skalƒÖ walki i uzupe≈ÇniajƒÖ je. W drugim starciu zw≈Çaszcza jest masa fajnych poziom√≥w, gdzie walczymy z przeciwnikami w pomieszczeniu, gdzie wszyscy skaczƒÖ od g√≥ry do do≈Çu, na platformach wypychajƒÖcych nas w r√≥≈ºne kierunki. W pamiƒôƒá zapadajƒÖ ogromne walki z drugiego starcia - jedna ≈õlizgajƒÖc siƒô po ogromnej po≈Çaci lodu, druga pod bramami "Wielkiej Katedry" - gdzie niezwykle klimatycznie zmienia siƒô niebo, wystƒôpujƒÖ zaciemnienia, deszcz meteoryt√≥w... Jest ten klimat. Wszystko okraszone dobrƒÖ muzyczkƒÖ do rozwa≈Çki.

Bardzo fajnie gra siƒô na kooperacji, ale tutaj mogƒÖ zdarzaƒá siƒô pewne b≈Çƒôdy. Pojawia≈Çy siƒô roz≈ÇƒÖczenia na skutek bad synca, czy mia≈Çem jednƒÖ sytuacjƒô gdzie mnie przenios≈Ço na kolejny poziom, a kolega szwƒôda≈Ç siƒô po starym. A jak przenios≈Ço go na nowy, to by≈Ça "zaburzona pozycja" - widzia≈Ç mnie gdzie indziej ni≈º by≈Çem, tak jak ja jego. Og√≥lnie gra lekko zwariowa≈Ça :P Ale my≈õlƒô ≈ºe na to, ≈ºe da≈Ço siƒô to rozwiƒÖzaƒá wczytaniem czy hostniƒôciem od nowa poziomu, to mo≈ºna to wybaczyƒá - zw≈Çaszcza, ≈ºe bawili≈õmy siƒô ≈õwietnie.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198136975055', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1676362616}
review:
The original Serious Sam experience (1st and 2nd Encounter included) with a updated engine.

Might be worth mentioning that back when Serious Sam came out, it felt like a breath of fresh air, a "sunny" and "open" "DooM clone", with cool weapons, enemies and maps.

If you want prettier graphics, I suggest the HD remasters/remakes, but this is the original experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995466528', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1678213515}
review: Sadly, SS didn't age as well as I hoped it would. For some reason, I don't remember it to be so full of monster closets, troll moments and just horrible design elements (the way splash damage works for example). All in all, instead of it being more akin to the timelessness of the original Painkiller, SS (both first and second encounter), end up being like those awkward early 3D games we thankfully left far behind.

review: Aside from a mediocre fan-made campaign and a couple of annoying bugs, Revolution is nevertheless the definitive way to enjoy the originals. Still, the re-release would have been better had the focus been on fixing ALL of the broken enemy spawns from the original and ironing out the bugs, and not on the new campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036564374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2060, 'last_played': 1672950834}
review:
This is a classic Serious Sam - it's great and even better.
Fluid controls, high responsiveness, sick guns, dumb quotes, picturesque scenery of ancient Egypt, Mexico, Babylon, Persia and of medieval, surprisingly good soundtracks and an absolute mass of alien abominations to shoot and mince. It will also work on literally any toaster surviving to this day.

What's unique about this release?
It combines both first and second encounters together. Backed by steam workshop this is the best way to play classics now. It adds a new "Bright Island" dlc-like campaign and a couple of secrets to let you use weapons from the forgotten "Serious Sam Warped Deathmatch" in few of the original levels (no balance is broken). As for the cons, people say there's a desync issue in multiplayer. Save loading times are longer than you'd expect, although it's to be expected as the game literally switches different versions of engine on the fly.

The Bright Island.
If you want short - play first two levels and drop it.
Long: I have very mixed feelings about it. The scenery is actually stunning, designers did a splendid job on it, you get to see things and environments you'd never encounter in the original games, such as alien bases, underground pyramids, even server rooms, using few new assets. You also get to play with new weapons, like beamgun, plasmathrower and miner. First level is great, second is beautiful and Crystal Cove is good. Sadly, difficulty seems to be all over the place and levels feel like few different people were working separately on their own. Spawns are either too hard, or too easy, many "big waves" are boring or trivial because of the lack of variety. On the other side of the spectrum, the room in Sunken Pyramid with the Beamgun or the portal room in Forlorn ruins must've been some of the worst experiences I've had on the serious engine and it's clear nobody even did a testrun of those or it was done on tourist. As you go deeper into the campaign, the game engine struggles maintaining the fps (I didn't even know this game can have low fps) and it gets worse as you progress. The final boss is actually very interesting, the moment I saw the room I expected a certain creature, but never expected it to be a sequence of those. Too bad they didn't put speed buffs there, as you just end up camping health as is. Final level is otherwise very underwhelming. I liked the new golems, hated the ugh zanns (bad hitbox, bs weapons) and disliked the new headless (fps killers in numbers, bs weapons). I have encountered both secret levels on my first blind run and I can't say I would have missed anything if I didn't encounter them. For the majority the campaign is very pretty, but doesn't play well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274518574', 'num_games_owned': 41, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3382, 'last_played': 1701095706}
review:
The guy who made bright island campaign should be banned from ever making a single map ever again.

I don't even know where to start. Optimization is horrible, if you have pretty average pc get ready for frame rates as low as 30. Most maps in the campaign are a walking simulator with huge, boring, blocky, open areas, none of the them have any detail to them. 2 secret levels are straight up alpha level quality. It also has the same problem TFE campaign had, where it just instantly drops enemies on top of you (some times arenas are way to small for the amount of enemies you are facing) and you are expected to just survive somehow through trial and error while spaming quick save button, but in this campaign it's cranked up to eleven. A lot of major arenas on serious difficulty are either piss easy or completely unbalanced (biggest offenders would be arenas in level 3 and last arena of forlorn ruins which is just straight up stupid on serious difficulty). All the new enemies use cheap recolored models of already existing enemies with gimmicks added to them. There also is a scaled down ugh-zan made into a common enemy and even that doesnt work properly, it has a janky hitbox and feels completely out of place. These are just the most glaring issues I listed.

I honeslty didn't expect it to be anywhere near perfect when I first started it, but I think after playing through this DISASTER of a campaign, it has legit scared me for life because of how bad of an experience it was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006496533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 2329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2292, 'last_played': 1693075239}
review:
Want a game where you shoot aliens in ancient Egypt? Then check out Serious Sam Classics: Revolution!

It's more on the earlier end of the FPS design spectrum... pretty much a skill based shooter like quake but with more room to manoeuvre and move in a pattern, dodging skeletal horse enemies while firing your double barrelled shotgun (Classic FPS)! The visuals of the games were improved somewhat but natural textures still by and large look quite unpleasant. Artificial stuff looks pretty good though.  The in-game secrets are great and was probably the reason I played the game until the end to a length of more than double the skill based shooter average length of 10 hours (And even that time was draining to me inspite of my love of the genre) and it proved to be surprisingly engrossing! Plus it's easy to run, has value for money and is an FPS with same-screen multiplayer (If setting up the controls is a bit of a faff and the remote play together function may have an issue)!

To see the more in depth review on The Cheapness YouTube channel:

author: {'steamid': '76561198103339127', 'num_games_owned': 786, 'num_reviews': 320, 'playtime_forever': 1393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1664046615}
review:
[h1]Running Backwards - but we are back at the start again, oh the irony[/h1]

So, you've happen to have Serious Sam 1:TFE and TSE?
Well, consider yourself lucky, since now you also have access to the free remastered version of both of these games.
Here's about the original games if you wonder:
1)https://steamcommunity.com/id/yuuuuki/recommended/41050/
2)https://steamcommunity.com/id/yuuuuki/recommended/41060/

[h1]The main features of the Revolution[/h1]
Besides the fact, that this was a fan-made mod, that Croteam managed to finish up, the mod includes
Playable both games, with all the modern support, glitchless graphic options, better controls and all that good stuff that easens the launch of both games nowadays. (we need more modern support like this for other old games)
There's also a 3-rd campaign now, which I will describe later.
New difficulty level that includes a random buff for all of the monsters
3 new weapons that are welcomed but not entirely needed
new varieties for existing monsters
New survival maps
Steam achievments
and I guess there's more.

[h1]New campaign and personal experience[/h1]
The most interesting feature - is the Bright Island. Basically, Sam got stuck between time and space. You will travel through 6+2 secret levels, experience a lot better level design than in the original games and also face new features of new difficulty level without the need for unlocking it.
The only problem - is the final boss - he is pretty tough.

As for the personal experience:
It feels like they tinkered with the game balance and the AI - you get more damage from explosions, some enemies will dodge your projectiles or even to try to flank you. I mean - great job, but its not the best idea for Serious Sam games.
There's a couple of new secrets and easter eggs for original campaigns but the new weapons there - are useless, they work best in the 3-rd campaign, to be honest.
I also had a funny rare bug, after finishing First Encounter after I started Second One immediately - the game bugged out and I think...it made me invisible for some reason. Enemies didn't cared about me, some traps didn't worked. I didnt care actually, since I thought it would be cool to just ran pass final level and be done with it...buuut the game fixed itself at the middle of it, well shoot, guess I need to start action again, what a shame.
Finally, I think I've had fun with new maps mostly because I  played original campaigns too much already.
Considering this fact and also some changes and final boss - now I just want to hunt down the ones who did all that made me frustrated as hell and mutilate them with Ghostbuster - the new weapon. Its slow, wastes ammo too fast and do no damage - hope they will suffer just as I am.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Still, I think its the best way to experience original First and Second encounters, since its easier to approach them this way. But if you are a purist, you won't miss much if you skip this version.

[h1]P.S. - about the Running Backwards in VR and Greece[/h1]
You thought I forgot about VR games and Greek Encounter?
It was tough but I managed to try it out. 
Greek Encounter was a pretty simple and very basic top-down shooter - about 20 minutes of gameplay. Not really good if you ask me. (you can find it on YouTube and Reddit)
As for the VR games...they are the same HD versions of Serious Sam 1 and also Serious Sam 3. But you have no balance, more movement speed, and the abiltity to use 2 guns at once...but with no reloading whatsoever. Just imagine 2 double shotguns that can shoot like machine guns and you get the idea. Still, if you have VR and just want more Sam then its your choice.
As for the Last Hope - about 2 hours of gameplay, but you stand in place and shoot everything that moves towards you - skippable.

author: {'steamid': '76561199159544430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3090, 'last_played': 1679823597}

author: {'steamid': '76561198414146466', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 125787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111841, 'last_played': 1696262592}
review:
Serious Sam is a part of my life and it is without a doubt my favorite game series. 
As a player with thousands of hours of gameplay in Campaign mode , i can say that Serious Sam : Revolution is the best option to play the Classic version of the First and Second Encounter.
    The reasons of playing the Revolution version are multiple and i will count right here:
 - One of the most important reasons is containing both first and second encounter in a single game
 - This version has Full HD resolution (1920x1080) and it was optimized for modern PC , along with split screen for multiplayer gameplay with maximum of 4 players.
 - Along with Both Encounters , Revolution comes with a new campaign called Bright Island made by the studio Aligator Pit and later optimized by Croteam.
 - 3 new weapons were added in the game hidden in the Serious Sam levels (Beam Gun "Ghostbuster which is a laser beam weapon for close-range encounters and can be found in the Alley of the Sphinxes in First Encounter, the Destructive Minelayer , a weapon that launches explosive mine traps which can be triggered by enemies stepping in the mines or by activating the mines which is found in the Land of the Damned in Second Encounter and the CDF-ST-005 Plasmathrower , an energy weapon pretty similar with XL2 Lasergun but with a slower fire rate and it has an alternate fire, it fires powerful plasma shots and it can be found in the Citadel in the Second Encounter.)
 - Alligator Pit added Survival mode with 4 levels that can be played solo or in co-op mode.
 - 2 new difficulties were added in the game , the Mental difficulty that was added from HD games which is literally Hard difficulty with invisible enemies and ball stretching I am Ugh-Zan difficulty which is Serious difficulty on Steroids with tougher enemies , and enemies that slows and burns the player.
 - The introduction of Steam Workshop , that allows the Serious Sam players to make creative and mind-blowing mods and custom levels in order to try something new in the game.
 - New enemies were added such as Beheaded-Commando , the Bio-mechanoid Spawner , Bio-mechanoid Dominant (a cannonball throwing freak) , elemental golems and Elder Arachnoid.
 - The most significant of the changes is a greatly-expanded versus mode. They added Capture the Flag and Control Zone from Seriously Warped Deathmatch, along with Serious Sam HD's Insta-Kill mode, in order to give versus players a lot more options.
    In conclusion , Serious Sam : Revolution is a better way to have fun in the gorgeous classic version of the Serious Sam First and Second Encounter and not that , but trying to play a variety of new custom levels and learning to create mods by using the Serious Editor.

author: {'steamid': '76561199033782005', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1688476637}
review: No reason to not buy this over the other versions. 2 bucks on sale, saves you 2 dollars full price, includes both classic encounters' original versions, is way cheaper than the HD versions so it's perfect for a budget gamer (and includes some HD balancing options for co-op!), a ton of customization, and much more. For me proper FOV options and widescreen support sell it enough, and I had no issues [i]encountered[/i] so far. Definitely a great way to start the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123878484', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1666126719}
review:
OK this game lets you play TFE and TSE. They mostly still same and we don't need to talk about them. They are greats on their ways.

They added a new campain called Bright Island. Let me say that this game originally developed by a compainy named Alligator Pit. So this campain is their creation. I want to talk about the campain. Campain is cannonically is between Mayan episodes and Persian episode. Story is about lost continent Mu. Sam needs to find a new timelock to get there out (as classic). Campain adds many more things. Normally it should be great but however they messed up with that. A lot of new enemies are off place and unbalanced. New weapons aren't that impressive (We have a minelayer WHY?) and campain does not have unique art style. It is just ripped of from other parts of the game. It has even a part where they even rip off some content from SS2. Yet in last levels somehow campain is painfully hard. Last part of the game made me loss my braincells.
Conculision, it is a bad campain don't even worth a try but as usual you are Sam fan that in need of playing it, play it. It won't be chaning for you.

This game has improvement over First game and tons of new options to use. Now you game freely play on modern systems without a worry. Also if you have any of the classics game, this game is free as in Fusion 2017. Or you don't have classics you have to buy it. It is cheap and ƒ∞f you buy it, classic games will be added in your steam libary.

Great for nostalgic return but nothing more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059833388', 'num_games_owned': 1263, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 2860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2486, 'last_played': 1708276583}
review:
The best way to play the original Serious Sam. 
Workshop support, Steamworks multiplayer, Survival mode, new multiplayer maps and modes, a wide array of settings to tinker with.

Just don't play Bright Island. It's ugly, boring and tedious with enemies getting stuck all the time and levels that are just way too big.

author: {'steamid': '76561198811539392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 11, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1710550807}
review: The xinput works on this version. Aka your controllers will actually be registered in this version. Spent hours trying to get my xbox 1 controllers to work with the classic versions. Not 100% sure but if you want to play the first and second assault with controllers you could probably take the All_01.gro or All_02.gro file and copy it over to the originals. Again not sure if these are the files that provide controller inputs but from looking around attempting to get xinput controller files for the Classic versions they seemed to come in .gro files.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142318655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 4145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4129, 'last_played': 1657312941}
review:
As much as I don't like modders who put their hands into the finished product, created by professionals and often spoil it, so much it was interesting and fun for me to play this game. I felt like a developer when I set up the graphics of the game and broke everything, but then I set everything up so cool that my eyes were happy (except for the moments when the game had 12 FPS).

I hadn't played the Bright Island levels before (don't even remember if it was in the parts I had already played), so it was new for me.

Thanks for developers of this game for the Split Screen mode, thanks to which you can get achievements with the bot. I see this implementation for the first time, it's just brilliant (I'm sure that somewhere a similar solution was implemented before, but I just haven't seen it). Also, many thanks for the game mutators, with which you can turn the game into a real bacchanalia, but at the same time get achievements faster.

Achievements in this game almost not duplicate achievements from SS HD TFE/TSE, which is good, because now you don't need to win over9000 times in dead online. There were very few really difficult and tedious achievements, and one that seemed simply impossible to get (I am Ugh-Zan) is obtained very simply, but by a different method, which personally raised questions in me as to why it even works and how this method was discovered. A lot of interesting things were discovered while completing the achievements are reading the guides.

In general, I have never regretted that I played this part of the Serious Sam. This version looks quite original and offers a number of interesting achievements. A great reason to play the old parts of the game again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2302, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1651693248}
review:
If you‚Äôre keeping count, this is the fourth version of The First and Second Encounters you can get on Steam, after HD, Classic, and Fusion. I‚Äôve talked about the quality of the HD versions, the improvements they got from being included in Fusion, and the interesting differences between them and Classic which keep the originals relevant. So where does that leave Revolution, a fan-touchup of Classic? Well, if you absolutely must play the originals, this is a fine way to do it. You get a few graphical and system improvements, on top of some extra fan-made content. I wouldn‚Äôt really consider that last bit much of a draw, honestly, but whether or not you appreciate the new maps and weapons, it‚Äôs more of the classic Serious Sam action you know and love.

To be specific, Revolution is a 64-bit sourceport of Serious Engine 1, combining TFE and TSE in one neat little package (and without the reprehensible Legend of the Beast DLC). It seems the aim here was to modernize the original Serious Sam adventures without giving them the full HD makeover, so these versions look and play very similar to Classic, but with modern graphical options and a cleaner UI. After playing the opening bits of both Encounters, I can definitely say this is an improvement over the Classic releases in subtle ways. The most apparent fixes are properly-scaling UI and better textures, of course, but the whole package runs notably better, too. All the strangely-moody atmosphere of TFE and cluttered landscapes of TSE are recreated here in an engine better suited to modern gaming.

However, there are some key differences here from the Classic and also HD versions. You get a whole new fan-made episode called Bright Island to play through, wherein Sam has been Timelocked out of time itself, and landed on some appropriately fanciful islands. These maps have a great deal of style and variety to them, but also tend to be overly massive, to the point of sometimes hitching the game. I also saw a fair bit of lighting weirdness, usually with full-bright or full-dark surfaces, that I didn‚Äôt see in the base game so I assume they‚Äôre map-making errors. And while the battles have some welcome variety to them, some are just not very well-designed. These devs like to surround the player but don‚Äôt always give enough space for that to work, so be prepared for Kleer or kamikazes to spawn in right on top of you at times. I even had a few moments of confusion and frustration when enemies would spawn inside the floor or walls, making them impossible to cross of my kill list.

Revolution doesn‚Äôt stop there, though. There are a few new weapons like a plasma gun, which is a lot like the laser cannon except the shots explode and it has a brutal shotgun alt-fire. I found these to be welcome additions in the Bright Island episode, but they also got worked into the original games as secrets. It‚Äôs not bad or anything, but if you‚Äôre a stickler for the unchanged original experience, this isn‚Äôt the version for you. You‚Äôve also got a new survival mode to try out if you just need walls of enemies to mow down, and who doesn‚Äôt need that in their Serious Sam? Ultimately though, if you‚Äôre not here for the fan episode (and I am not), there‚Äôs not much reason to recommend this one. HD is still the best way to experience The First and Second Encounters, and aside from quality-of-life improvements and some random new guns, this isn‚Äôt so different from the perfectly okay Classics. But hey, you get this free with the Classics anyway, so why not, right?



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561198158332158', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 5395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4258, 'last_played': 1696253276}
review:
Serious Sam Classics: Revolution is a fan-made project aimed to bundle The First Encounter and The Second Encounter as well as some community-made goods into one game.

Revolution is basically The First & Second Encounter plus Bright Island campaign with lots of new maps. There is basically no difference in graphics or gameplay compared to The First & Second Encounter. It even kind of has the same bugs. But apart from that, here what's different:

Revolution features a brand-new community-made campaign called Bright Island, featuring 6 main maps and 2 secret maps, all worth playing not only because of the great music and level design, but mostly for their size. Those 8 maps are enormous. It can take 30 - 45 minutes just to get through one of these maps! It's definitely a view every single time.

There are also three new weapons, the XL4-P Beam Gun (also known as the scrapped "Ghostbuster" weapon from The First Encounter), the CDF-ST-005 Plasmathrower and MKII-B Minelayer (both weapons from The Second Encounter's "Seriously Warped Deathmatch" mod). These weapons have actually been added into certain maps of The First & Second Encounter campaigns. Sadly, the original maps weren't made with those weapons in mind, leaving the player with scarce ammo for them or just not many occasions to use them for.

The Bright Island campaign features all these weapons too, but this time they are an integral part of the map design, giving the player a reason to pick these guns. The new campaign and some new survival maps feature a lot of new enemies to fight against! They are more dangerous and unique, making the gameplay staying interesting after even the 500th corridors of plain shooting.

Most of the achievements for this game can be achieved alone, even the multiplayer ones. Except for the one where there are 8 players needed. Good luck finding someone to help out! Still, the game is pretty fun and there a lot more custom maps that can be played just like community campaigns.

Revolution doesn't have any kind of fire rate bug on the XL2 Lasergun or the Tommygun, but it does occasionally make the player shoot randomly to the side instead of where the crosshair is pointing, for some reason. It usually happens while strafing and changing weapons at the same time, but this bug also appears pretty rarely. It shouldn't be a game-breaker. 

What could be a problem, is the mild optimization of rendering the Bright Island campaign maps. Since they are massive, the game sometimes just starts lagging if the player looks somewhere inconvenient. This may not occur on better hardware, but this is my experience on an AMD Radeon RX 580.

Of course, this game also features a lot of stuff in multiplayer, but since the multiplayer is practically dead, there can't be said anymore than "the maps look interesting".

Is this game worth a shot? Definitely. The graphics may look kind of dated and sometimes the game is clunky but apart from all of that, it's a fantastic game, giving the player a lot to do and lots to see. Besides, there's this "I am Ugh-Zan" difficulty that's way harder than your average "Serious" difficulty...

author: {'steamid': '76561198441943642', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 4060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1707533754}
review:
This game is really fun but it is not for everyone. To get things straight this game is hard, like REALLY HARD. This game is not for casuals in my opinion, with tsunami storms of monsters always in your face can make anyone have feelings of both stressful anxiety and pure guns-blazing badassery! 

This in my opinion is both Serious Sam's greatest strength and weakness, as shown in levels where enemy placement like in wide open valley's like the Egyptian dessert stages are for me peak Serious Sam goodness.
On the opposite side though levels like the ghetto and suburb stages where they are filled with enemies, but you cant spot them out as good because of the annoying buildings in the way as well with Serious Sam's dickish enemy placement with hit scan enemies which can drain all your health in a couple of seconds, and this is still on the normal difficulty mode.

Again as mention earlier Serious Sam is nothing compared to games like Doom or Duke Nukem where they focused on both action and puzzle solving. Serious Sam has more connections with old arcade styled games like Contra, Ghost's N Goblins, and Gauntlet. So if you like more brutally difficult arcade type games like those you will have a blast with this game like how I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981638563', 'num_games_owned': 3986, 'num_reviews': 516, 'playtime_forever': 6871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1647698742}
review:
[h1]‚ÄúI'm Duke Dick and I will... sh*t down your pants and... rip open your brain and set your ass on fire.‚Äù
~[i]Morgan Freeman ([url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IQnixV5vJk4]Boet Schouwink's parody[/url])[/i][/h1]

So, commercial mods, huh? Can't... say I'm a big fan of those. Even though I admit, sometimes those can do magic. For example, you may remember [b]Rewolf Software[/b]'s [url=https://www.moddb.com/games/gunman-chronicles][b]Gunman Chronicles[/b][/url]. Very nice and daring mod for [b]VALVe[/b]'s [b]Half-Life[/b], which even got physical release by [b]Sierra[/b] in [b]2000[/b] ([b]Mod DB[/b] version works perfectly fine with [b]Steam[/b] version of [b]Half-Life[/b], make sure to check it out if you missed it back in the days, totally worth it). Also, [b]Half-Life[/b] itself got surprisingly awesome remake called [b]Black Mesa[/b], created by [b]Crowbar Collective[/b]. Because yes, unlike [b]Nintendo[/b], [b]Gaben[/b] and his guys aren't a-holes and actually allow people to do things. In other words, commercial mods [i]can[/i] be good. The problem is -  creating a good mod is almost as hard as creating a new game from scratch. A-a-and... let's just say that not everybody has what it takes. Dutch team called [b]Alligator Pit[/b]? Unfortunately for us all, they did not.

But OK. First of all ‚Äì what the heck is [b]Serious Sam Classics: Revolution[/b]? Well, long story short, the idea was to take the first two ‚Äúencounters‚Äù of the original [b]Serious Sam[/b] game by [b]Croteam[/b], tweak things a bit, add some new enemies and weapons, while also adding a whole new ‚Äúencounter‚Äù / story episode. Doesn't sound bad on paper, right? Well, in reality it is. It [i]is[/i] bad. And first of all ‚Äì this product is a technical disaster. Which... is a big surprise to me. I mean yes, it's an old mod, which was abandoned by [b]Alligator Pit[/b] years and years ago. [i]But[/i] [b]Croteam[/b], who are always looking for more ways to sell us their old [b]Serious Sam[/b] games again, actually took over the project and finished it all by themselves, so, like I said, I'm [i]really[/i] surprised to see this product being in such an awful shape. I mean, it was finished by the guys who made the original game. What the [i]f*ck[/i] with all the technical difficulties?!

The first thing I've experienced in [b]Serious Sam Classics: Revolution[/b] was... a black screen. That's right, I've started a new game and... everything went black. Re-starting the game didn't help and the only way to fix it was to manually delete the config file. OOOK, [b]PC[/b] mustard race ahoy, matey, we can live with that. I've deleted the config file, tried again and guess what? I was finally able to start playing. Except... at the very beginning of [b]The First Encounter[/b], [b]Sam[/b]... spawned in the mid air. And just kept flying. In other words, for whatever f*cked up reason out there, the game just spawned me with that flying cheat enabled by default. And the only way to disable it was through console. Which instantly disabled the achievements... For f*ck sake, [b]Croteam[/b], [i]seriously?[/i] I mean, unlike the [b]HD[/b] remakes of the first two ‚Äúencounters‚Äù, this product doesn't even use the new engine. It's still the same ol' [b]Sam[/b] on the same ol' [b]Serious Engine 1[/b]. Well, technically, the engine was tweaked a bit to include full [b]64-bit[/b] compatibility, so, we can actually call it [b]Serious Engine 1.5[/b], but still, what the [i]f*ck[/i] with all this technical disaster? Because [i]no[/i], the problems don't end here. There are brand new bugs (they've actually fixed some of the old ones, the weapon field of view bug included, but [i]man[/i], they've added tons of the new ones), the game will crash with no apparent reason, etc, etc, etc.

Which ultimately destroys the entire purpose of having the first two ‚Äúencounters‚Äù in here. I mean, the original goal was to give us the ultimate [b]Serious Sam[/b] experience. To fix bugs, to tweak things, to bring back the weapon that was cut from the original game by [b]Croteam[/b] ([b]XL4-P Ghostbuster[/b] is back, suckaz!) and add some of the new ones ([b]CDF-ST-005 Plasmathrower[/b] and [b]MKII-B Minelayer[/b] from [b]Seriously Warped Deathmatch[/b] mod for [b]Second Encounter[/b] will make an appearance here), add some new enemies (mostly the altered versions of the old ones, but still), add a survival mode, etc. Like I said, it was supposed to be an ideal version of the first [b]Sam[/b] for pure old school joy. But in such a terrible shape? The entire purpose of having something like this disappears. Just go for the originals and you'll have much more fun. Even without the changes I've mentioned.

Now, guess it's time to talk 'bout the exclusive new ‚Äúencounter‚Äù / story chapter. I mean, let's just forget about re-worked versions of the original two episodes. Those don't worth it. But what about the exclusive new campaign you won't find in any other version of the game? Well... I... can't say it's an utter garbage. So-called [b]Bright Island[/b] campaign comes with the whole eight levels that were made from scratch, it's about five hours long (as long as you'll go for all the secrets and won't just rush to the exit), there are attempts to make level design more complicated, there are boss battles, one of which is actually the most complicated boss battle you can see in the original [b]Serious Sam[/b] (doesn't say much, since boss battles in [b]Serious Sam[/b] games were always dull as F, but still), there are new assets, which means that you won't get ‚Äúmore of exactly the same‚Äù feeling, etc. In other words, quite a lot of content.

The problem is ‚Äì nothing of that feels like the real deal. Like a high quality stand-alone product. Instead, it feels... Well, it feels exactly like what it is. An ultra-low budget mod. Pretty noobish one too. Not... [i]completely[/i] noobish, I can give it that, but still, pretty noobish. Right from the very first minute, you'll start getting that ‚Äú[b]Mod DB[/b]‚Äù feeling. I mean... I'm not trying to say that there's something wrong with [b]Mod DB[/b], but you know how it is. Most of the time there's a significant difference between polished commercial product and a homemade mod. And [b]Bright Island[/b]? It's just that. A rough and clunky homemade mod. With some really stupid decisions (for example, those nasty platformer-like parts are laughably bad).

To be fair, though, this product is free for everybody who owns [b]Croteam[/b]'s first two ‚Äúencounters‚Äù. So, it [i]looks[/i] like nobody tries to scam anybody with this product, bu-u-ut... they actually do. [b]Serious Sam Classics: Revolution[/b] [i]is[/i] a scamish product. See, [b]Steam[/b] has the official mod support. You've created a mod? You can officially release it in [b]Steam[/b]. You want it to be free? You can do that. For example, a great Czech team did exactly that with their [b]Gothic II[/b] mod called [b]The Chronicles Of Myrtana: Archolos[/b]. Even though their product is actually better than the official [b]Gothic II[/b] game (feel free to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/letande/recommended/1467450]check out my review[/url] for details), it's completely free and is marked as mod in [b]Steam[/b] store. With [b]SSC: R[/b]? It's different. They're actually selling it for [b]$9.99[/b]. Which is wrong. For many reasons. First ‚Äì there's a chance that people will buy it before the two official ‚Äúencounters‚Äù. I mean, this product makes you believe that it's a good deal, thanks to how both ‚Äúencounters‚Äù are included, but after seeing all the technical disaster, there's no other way but to go for the originals. Also, having this as a free bonus for buying both the official chapters may actually improve sales. Like I said, pretty scamish approach. One way or another, though, it's a bad product. And as long as you're not a die-hard [b]Sam[/b] fan who wants to play every single mod out there, this product is an instant no-no for you. Dixi.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993008418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1647187302}
review: Serious Sam commits every game design sin in the book. It is unfair, mean-spirited, and a borderline kaizo game. The application of skill is not so much important as rote memorization of enemy placements and/or a rigorous quicksave/quickload routine. Its greatest sin is that it's actually quite fun, and you'll be cruising along for minutes at a time having a great time before it pulls some bullshit on you that saps away any goodwill you had towards the game. Not recommended, especially not this rerelease which has a ton of technical issues the original game did not have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198894630362', 'num_games_owned': 312, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 3097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1685920429}
review:
Definitive version of Serious Sam to play, over the classic versions, HD remakes, and especially Fusion, which has been left abandoned by Croteam. At least this, unlike that, is a finished product. The package suffers from some optimization issues in the added campaign "Bright Island" (which is also way better than people give it credit for, btw), but the frame issues I've suffered from are tolerable enough, and I say that playing it on an Idaho potato of a PC

Inherently, it's more colorful and visually stimulating than the HD versions, and it comes with Steam workshop support as well as quicker weapon-swapping than the base, vanilla classic games. Also, obviously, comes with the benefits of being in Serious Engine 1 where gravity tricks and physics are actually a thing, unlike the base HD games and Fusion, where such features are impossible to achieve being Serious Engines 3 and 4 simply lack such features. Serious Engine 1's set of features allows for greater arena variety, more fun character movement involving slope physics, and setpieces like kamikazes hitching rides on harpies or werebulls. 

If you're primarily playing singleplayer, can't recommend enough. But that said, be warned about the dogshit netcode. Prepare to uninstall all your mods and have a fresh reinstall if you don't want 100+ ping doing anything multiplayer related.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024953074', 'num_games_owned': 8928, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 2566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2566, 'last_played': 1643890621}
review:
It's classic Serious Sam. This version plays well enough that I enjoyed going through TFE and TSE again. It has some random stutters and other performance issues that I couldn't figure out, at least on my system. I also don't know if it's always been the case with these games, but the audio felt really "muddy", where I had a lot of difficulty determining which direction certain noises were coming from. There was also a weird semi-common projectile bug, where fired projectiles would have the firing angle completely different to your actual facing direction, which actually dealt heavy damage to me on more than one occasion due to a rocket doing an almost 90 degree turn into some wall near me.

The new campaign (Bright Island) is not very good. First off, it runs like utter shit, dropping as low as ~20 FPS in certain parts. Gameplay-wise, it starts decent, but gradually devolves into trash. Level 3 is the worst one of the lot with its cramped and gimmicky fights that drag on forever. All the new campaign enemies are just roided up bullet sponge reskins and are all a chore to kill.

The new guns Revolution implements also kinda suck. The Plasmathrower is the least bad weapon, but it usually just felt like a backup ammo pool for when all the good guns were out. The Minelayer is completely worthless, since it requires you to either get close enough to nuzzle the enemy's bulge, or to drop them in front of distant enemies hoping to get a kill or two you could have gotten with literally any other weapon in less time and with less effort. The Beam Gun is just an excruciatingly shit version of the Lasergun that deals less damage less reliably and at about 2-3 times the cost.

As for The First and Second Encounters, they're still mostly solid enough that I want to recommend this. If you already own some version of those games, I don't know if you'd need this. This is a pretty feeble "Yes" from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096811507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 266, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1684160647}
review:
[h1]Rating[/h1]
7/10

[h1]Intro[/h1]
If you've already played The First Encounter and The Second Encounter, I recommend picking this up for the Bright Island campaign. It's not perfect, but neither is the entire Serious Sam series and is still worth  playing.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Great soundtrack.
+ Good replay value.
+ Great enemy variety.
+ Great weapon variety.
+ Campaign cooperative.
+ Steam Workshop support.
+ Good aesthetics and graphics.
+ Exploring side areas rewards you with goodies.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Unbalanced difficulty at times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091961482', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1644019810}
review: The game's formula gets old fast. But for a dollar sale, you get what you pay for. The first and second encounter is riddled with big, sprawling arenas with hundreds of enemies. A lot of spawns are very cheap too, so expect to save/load often. It's fun, but the game quickly becomes a chore to finish. The movement is so basic as well, having a sprint button or at the very least gaining speed through rocket jumping would have made traversal a lot faster and more fun too. After finishing the first encounter I had my fill. Similar to Wolfenstein 3D, it's very fun to hop in and kill some stuff, and that's about it.
